An endomorphism span E:V→VE:V\to VE:V→V composes with itself nnn times giving the span E×Vn:V→V.E^{\times_V n}:V\to V.E×V​n:V→V.

An endomorphism bimodule Ω:A→A\Omega:A\to AΩ:A→A composes with itself nnn times giving the bimodule Ω⊗An:A→A.\Omega^{\otimes_A n}:A\to A.Ω⊗A​n:A→A.

Given a set SSS, there two ways to obtain algebras:
{}

  1. K[S],K[S],K[S], i.e. the formal linear combinations of elements of SSS.
  2. KS,K^S,KS, i.e. functions from SSS to KKK with product defined pointwise.

{}

{}

Bim→Cospan(Alg).\mathsf{Bim\to Cospan(Alg)}.Bim→Cospan(Alg).

Eric Forgy (Jan 14 2021 at 01:18):

A found this fact to be pretty cool...

A category internal to some category CCC is the same as a monad in Span(C)\mathsf{Span(C)}Span(C).

So anywhere I see "category internal to CCC", I can think "monad in Span(C)\mathsf{Span(C)}Span(C)"

Eric Forgy (Jan 14 2021 at 01:26):

From the nLab:

Here is the slick definition: let SSS be a category with pullbacks. Then the bicategory Prof(S)\mathsf{Prof}(S)Prof(S) of internal categories, profunctors and transformations in SSS is defined to be Mod(Span(S))\mathsf{Mod(Span}(S))Mod(Span(S)), the category of monads and bimodules in Span(S)\mathsf{Span}(S)Span(S), the bicategory of spans in SSS.

So an internal profunctor C⇸DC⇸DC⇸D between internal categories CCC and DDD is a bimodule from CCC to DDD. An internal presheaf on CCC is a right CCC-module, or equivalently a bimodule 1⇸C1⇸C1⇸C, where 111 is the discrete category on the terminal object of SSS (as long as SSS has one, of course).

The notation Ω⊗A′Ω′\Omega\otimes_{A'}\Omega'Ω⊗A′​Ω′ makes me want to think of bimodules as spans (or cospans)...

I believe you're stuck because bimodules are not a special case of spans. Spans (of sets, for example) are a special case of bimodules.

I explained it here:

  • John Baez, Spans versus bimodules, August 4, 2008.

When you understand this you'll be happy. I tried to explain it here on Zulip a while back, but you probably weren't desperate enough back then.

John Baez (Jan 14 2021 at 01:38):

The answers to the puzzles are the explanation. The answer to this puzzle:

Puzzle 3: What’s a bimodule of a pair of monoid objects in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm op}Setop?

is a span of sets!

John Baez (Jan 14 2021 at 01:40):

The bimodules you like to think about are bimodules in (Vect,⊗)(\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes)(Vect,⊗). But those are just a special case of a more general concept, and you need to go up a notch in generality to see that spans are also bimodules. It goes like this, briefly:

A set is a monoid object in the monoidal category (Setop,+)(\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}, +)(Setop,+).

We can define bimodules for monoid objects in any monoidal category.

A span of sets is a bimodule in (Setop,+)(\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}},+)(Setop,+).

John Baez (Jan 14 2021 at 01:43):

I don't expect this to be extremely easy to understand, but it's also not extremely hard.

Puzzle 1: What’s a monoid object in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop?

The "object" is a set XXX, but for this to be a monoid object, we need a multiplication

μ:X×X→X.\mu: X\times X\to X.μ:X×X→X.

and a unit

η:∗→X\eta: *\to Xη:∗→X

satisfying the conditions. I don't think the answer is complete without specifying those :thinking:

Attempt #1: Before looking at Puzzle #2

I think a multiplication X×X→XX\times X\to XX×X→X in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a function X→X×XX\to X\times XX→X×X in Set\mathsf{Set}Set and the only function that would make sense to me is
{}
x↦(x,x)∈X×X.x\mapsto (x,x)\in X\times X.x↦(x,x)∈X×X.
{}
A unit ∗→X*\to X∗→X in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a function X→∗X\to *X→∗ in Set\mathsf{Set}Set and that is unique since ∗*∗ is terminal.

A quick doodle confirms these satisfy associativity and unit laws.

Attempt #2: After looking at Puzzle #2, but before looking at Puzzle #3

I now see that I really wanted my monoid object to be a set of functions [X,X][X,X][X,X] (or End(X)\mathsf{End}(X)End(X)).

Then multiplication [X,X]×[X,X]→[X,X][X,X]\times [X,X]\to [X,X][X,X]×[X,X]→[X,X] is just composition of functions
{}
f×g↦f∘gf\times g \mapsto f\circ gf×g↦f∘g
{}
and the unit ∗→[X,X]*\to [X,X]∗→[X,X] is the identity function
{}
∙↦1X.\bullet\mapsto 1_X.∙↦1X​.

I don't actually see anything wrong with Attempt #1 though, so I think both might be correct. In that case, it means composition of endofunctions in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is the opposite of the diagonal map of endofunctions in Set.\mathsf{Set}.Set.

Attempt #3: After looking at Puzzle #3

After attempting Puzzle #3, I think I need to come back here again.

There are actually two types of monoid objects in Setop.\mathsf{Set^{op}}.Setop. The first is the one in Attempt #2 above, i.e. the set of functions [X,X][X,X][X,X] (or End(X)\mathsf{End}(X)End(X)).

The second type of monoid object, maybe denote it [X,X]op[X,X]^\mathsf{op}[X,X]op (or Endop(X)\mathsf{End^{op}}(X)Endop(X)). This monoid object is the same set of functions, but multiplication / composition
{}
[X,X]op×[X,X]op→[X,X]op[X,X]^\mathsf{op}\times[X,X]^\mathsf{op}\to[X,X]^\mathsf{op}[X,X]op×[X,X]op→[X,X]op
{}
is reversed, i.e.
{}
f×g↦g∘f.f\times g\mapsto g\circ f.f×g↦g∘f.

Puzzle 2: What’s a module of a monoid object in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop?

We're looking for an object, i.e. set, XXX and a monoid object AAA together with an action
{}
α:A×X→X.\alpha: A\times X\to X.α:A×X→X.

Attempt #1

I think this action should be
{}
eval:[X,X]×X→X,eval:(f,x)↦f(x).\mathsf{eval}: [X,X]\times X\to X,\quad \mathsf{eval}: (f,x) \mapsto f(x).eval:[X,X]×X→X,eval:(f,x)↦f(x).
{}
This is true for every set XXX in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop so every set XXX is an End(X)\mathsf{End}(X)End(X)-module.

Attempt #2: After looking at Puzzle #3

Referring to Attempt #3 in Puzzle #1, there are actually two kinds of modules in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop corresponding to the two types of monoid objects.
{}

  1. A left End(X)\mathsf{End}(X)End(X)-module is a set XXX and an action αL:End(X)×X→X.\alpha_L : \mathsf{End}(X)\times X\to X.αL​:End(X)×X→X.
  2. A right End(X)\mathsf{End}(X)End(X)-module is a set XXX and an action αR:Endop(X)×X→X.\alpha_R : \mathsf{End^{op}}(X)\times X\to X.αR​:Endop(X)×X→X.

{}
In both cases, the action is function evaluation.

Eric Forgy (Jan 14 2021 at 11:39):

Puzzle 3: What’s a bimodule of a pair of monoid objects in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop?

A bimodule would be a set XXX with compatible left and right actions.

Let
{}
L=End(X)×XL = \mathsf{End}(X)\times XL=End(X)×X
{}
and
{}
R=Endop(X)×XR = \mathsf{End^{op}}(X)\times XR=Endop(X)×X
{}
so that the actions can be written
{}
αL:L→XandαR:R→X.\alpha_L: L\to X\quad\text{and}\quad\alpha_R: R\to X.αL​:L→XandαR​:R→X.
{}

Together, the actions form a cospan
{}
L→X←RL\rightarrow X\leftarrow RL→X←R
{}
and pulling this back enforces their compatibility resulting in a span
{}
L←L×XR→R.L\leftarrow L\times_X R\rightarrow R.L←L×X​R→R.
{}
We can go one step further by forming the spans
{}
End(X)←L→X\mathsf{End}(X)\leftarrow L\rightarrow XEnd(X)←L→X
{}
X←R→Endop(X)X\leftarrow R\rightarrow \mathsf{End^{op}}(X)X←R→Endop(X)
{}
so that the composition of these two spans is
{}
End(X)←L×XR→Endop(X).\mathsf{End}(X)\leftarrow L\times_X R\rightarrow\mathsf{End^{op}}(X).End(X)←L×X​R→Endop(X).

John Baez (Jan 14 2021 at 15:52):

Eric Forgy said:

Puzzle 1: What’s a monoid object in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop?

The "object" is a set XXX, but for this to be a monoid object, we need a multiplication

μ:X×X→X.\mu: X\times X\to X.μ:X×X→X.

and a unit

η:∗→X\eta: *\to Xη:∗→X

satisfying the conditions. I don't think the answer is complete without specifying those :thinking:

Attempt #1: Before looking at Puzzle #2

I think a multiplication X×X→XX\times X\to XX×X→X in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a function X→X×XX\to X\times XX→X×X in Set\mathsf{Set}Set and the only function that would make sense to me is
{}
x↦(x,x)∈X×X.x\mapsto (x,x)\in X\times X.x↦(x,x)∈X×X.
{}
A unit ∗→X*\to X∗→X in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a function X→∗X\to *X→∗ in Set\mathsf{Set}Set and that is unique since ∗*∗ is terminal.

A quick doodle confirms these satisfy associativity and unit laws.

Right! And the really cool part is that this is the only possible choice of maps μ:X→X×X\mu: X \to X \times Xμ:X→X×X and η:X→1\eta: X \to 1η:X→1 obeying (co)associativity and the (co)unit laws. (We usually put the word "co" in here since the maps are going backwards.) So while in Set\mathsf{Set}Set you need to specify μ\muμ and η\etaη to say how we are treating our set XXX as a monoid, in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}Setop you don't: there's only one choice!

John Baez (Jan 14 2021 at 15:57):

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

John Baez said:

John mentioned already what monoidal product you should be using here in the message quoted above :wink:

But my remark was probably confusing, because the coproduct + in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}Setop is exactly what we usually call the product ×\times× in Set\mathsf{Set}Set. Anyway, this is the monoidal product I want: the coproduct in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}Setop, which we should probably write as ×\times× because it's the familiar set

X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}X \times Y = \{(x,y) : x \in X, y \in Y\}X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}

which is the product in Set\mathsf{Set}Set.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) (Jan 14 2021 at 16:00):

John Baez (Jan 14 2021 at 16:06):

Sure!

Anyway, Eric was completely correct in his first attempt to solve Puzzle 1.

Here's a more general way to think about this puzzle. In any monoidal category where the monoidal structure is given by coproduct, every object xxx becomes a monoid in a unique way.

The unit η:0→x\eta: 0 \to xη:0→x is unique because 000 is initial. The left and right unit laws force μ:x+x→x\mu: x + x \to xμ:x+x→x to be the codiagonal or 'fold' map ∇:x+x→x\nabla: x + x \to x∇:x+x→x.

John Baez (Jan 14 2021 at 16:11):

Δ\DeltaΔ is associative so xxx becomes a monoid this way. In fact it's commutative.

John Baez (Jan 14 2021 at 16:12):

Even better, the maps η\etaη are Δ\DeltaΔ are natural, every morphism in our category becomes a morphism of commutative monoids.

Bimodules vs Spans

  • Puzzle 1
  • Puzzle 2
  • Puzzle 3

There, we learned that in (Setop,×,∗)(\mathsf{Set^{op}},\times,*)(Setop,×,∗):

  • A monoid object AAA is a set with multiplication given by the diagonal map.
  • An AAA-module XXX is a function X→A.X\to A.X→A.
  • An (A,B)(A,B)(A,B)-module XXX is a span A←X→B.A\leftarrow X\rightarrow B.A←X→B.
  • Tensoring an (A,B)(A,B)(A,B)-bimodule XXX with a (B,C)(B,C)(B,C)-bimodule YYY is an (A,C)(A,C)(A,C)-bimodule X×BYX\times_B YX×B​Y corresponding to the composition of the respective spans

John Baez (Jan 15 2021 at 20:59):

Yes, that's a nice summary!

So: spans are a special case of the general theory of bimodules.

Then you can have some fun as follows:

Given monoidal categories CCC and DDD, and a monoidal functor F:C→DF: C \to DF:C→D, FFF maps monoid objects in CCC to monoid objects in DDD in an obvious way, and bimodules to bimodules in an obvious way, preserving composition up to isomorphism. (Details left as an exercise.)

So, we can use a monoidal functor

F:(Setop,×)→(Vect,⊗) F: (\mathsf{Set}^{\rm op}, \times) \to (\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes) F:(Setop,×)→(Vect,⊗)

to turn monoid objects in (Setop,×) (\mathsf{Set}^{\rm op}, \times)(Setop,×), which are just sets, to monoid objects in (Vect,⊗) (\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes) (Vect,⊗), which are just algebras, and turn bimodules in (Setop,×) (\mathsf{Set}^{\rm op}, \times)(Setop,×), which are just spans of sets, to monoid objects in (Vect,⊗) (\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes) (Vect,⊗), which are just bimodules, in a manner preserving composition.

I'm a little confused here, but I think it works better to use finite sets, since I think I know a very nice monoidal functor

(FinSetop,×)→(Vect,⊗) (\mathsf{FinSet}^{\rm op}, \times) \to (\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes) (FinSetop,×)→(Vect,⊗)

which does not extend to infinite sets. This monoidal functor sends any finite set XXX to kXk^XkX, where kkk is the field we're using to define Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect, and it sends a function f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y to the pullback linear map f∗:kY→kXf^\ast: k^Y \to k^Xf∗:kY→kX. Note this contravariance is what we need, to deal with the "op".

John Baez (Jan 15 2021 at 21:01):

I believe this is a very nice way to turn spans of finite sets into bimodules, in such a way that composition is preserved up to isomorphism. I think you want to use this in your work.

John Baez (Jan 15 2021 at 21:04):

If you need to use infinite sets I think things get a bit tricky.

John Baez (Jan 15 2021 at 22:00):

The point is this: for finite sets we have

kX×Y≅kX⊗kY k^{X \times Y} \cong k^X \otimes k^Y kX×Y≅kX⊗kY

but if both XXX and YYY are infinite this is false.

Thus, one can show the contravariant functor sending a finite set XXX to kXk^XkX and a function f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y to f∗:kY→kXf^\ast : k^Y \to k^Xf∗:kY→kX is monoidal, giving a monoidal functor

(FinSetop,×)→(Vect,⊗) (\mathsf{FinSet}^{\text{op}}, \times) \to (\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes) (FinSetop,×)→(Vect,⊗)

but this procedure does not give a monoidal functor

(Setop,×)→(Vect,⊗) (\mathsf{Set}^{\text{op}}, \times) \to (\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes) (Setop,×)→(Vect,⊗)

Various attempted workarounds seem to have various problems, which I could explain.

Eric Forgy (Jan 15 2021 at 22:05):

You've explained to me a couple times how there are two ways to get a vector space from a set, i.e. kSk^SkS and k[S]k[S]k[S]. Does the other way, i.e. k[S]k[S]k[S] suffer the same restriction to finite sets? In that case, we want k[X×Y]≅k[X]⊗k[Y].k[X\times Y] \cong k[X]\otimes k[Y].k[X×Y]≅k[X]⊗k[Y].

John Baez (Jan 15 2021 at 22:07):

There is a covariant functor sending any set XXX to k[X]k[X]k[X], the free vector space on XXX and any function f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y to a certain obvious linear map f∗:k[X]→k[Y]f_\ast: k[X] \to k[Y]f∗​:k[X]→k[Y]. This construction obeys

k[X×Y]≅k[X]⊗k[Y] k[X \times Y] \cong k[X] \otimes k[Y]k[X×Y]≅k[X]⊗k[Y]

for any pair of sets XXX or YYY, so we get a monoidal functor

(Set,×)→(Vect,⊗) (\mathsf{Set}, \times) \to (\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes) (Set,×)→(Vect,⊗)

but note: the "op" is not there now! So this sends monoids in (Set,×) (\mathsf{Set}, \times)(Set,×) - that is, ordinary monoids - to algebras.

We can also think of the above functor as a monoidal functor

(Setop,×)→(Vectop,⊗) (\mathsf{Set}^{\text{op}}, \times) \to (\mathsf{Vect}^{\text{op}}, \otimes) (Setop,×)→(Vectop,⊗)

This sends sets (monoid objects in (Setop,×)(\mathsf{Set}^{\text{op}}, \times)(Setop,×)) to coalgebras (monoid objects in (Vectop,⊗) (\mathsf{Vect}^{\text{op}}, \otimes) (Vectop,⊗)).

Eric Forgy (Jan 15 2021 at 22:11):

John Baez (Jan 15 2021 at 22:13):

I will say this: a lot of times when people naively think they need algebras, it turns out coalgebras would work. Finite-dimensional algebras are practically the same as finite-dimensional coalgebras, since the dual of the former is the latter and vice versa, and dualizing twice gets you back where you started. That fails in the infinite-dimensional case. So the need for coalgebras becomes more visible in the infinite-dimensional case, which is exactly the problem we're running up against now.

John Baez (Jan 15 2021 at 22:35):

It's okay with working with isomorphism classes of bimodules until you want to talk about something like an element of a bimodule, or a homomorphism between bimodules.

There's no such thing as an element of an isomorphism classes of bimodules. There's no such thing as a homomorphism between isomorphism classes of bimodules. For these you need actual bimodules.

An isomorphism class is like a slippery greased pig twisting around so fast you can't grab any individual part of it. All you can say is "yup, it's a pig".

Given a monoidal category (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1):

  • Every object in CCC is a monoid object in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).
  • Every span R←M→SR\leftarrow M\rightarrow SR←M→S in CCC is an (R,S)(R,S)(R,S)-bimodule in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).

Since every morphism f:M→Sf:M\to Sf:M→S is equivalent to a span
{}
M←1M→fS,M\overset{1}{\leftarrow}M\overset{f}{\rightarrow} S,M←1M→fS,
{}
this also implies:

  • Every morphism f:M→Sf:M\to Sf:M→S in CCC is a left SSS-module in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).

Right modules are a little trickier.

  • Every span R←M→1MR\leftarrow M\overset{1}{\rightarrow} MR←M→1M is a right RRR-module in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).

Eric Forgy (Jan 16 2021 at 19:45):

Btw, I can hear John's voice in my head, so let me explain what I mean by Bim(C,⊗,1)\mathsf{Bim}(C,\otimes,1)Bim(C,⊗,1) :sweat_smile:

The (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1) part just means a monoidal category.

Bim(C,⊗,1)\mathsf{Bim}(C,\otimes,1)Bim(C,⊗,1) is a bicategory whose

  • Objects are monoid objects in (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1)
  • Morphisms are (R,S)(R,S)(R,S)-bimodules in (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1)
  • 2-morphisms are bimodule homomorphisms

Eric Forgy (Jan 16 2021 at 19:49):

Similarly, Cospan(C,⊗,1)\mathsf{Cospan}(C,\otimes,1)Cospan(C,⊗,1) is a bicategory whose

  • Objects are monoid objects in (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1)
  • Morphisms are cospans R→M←SR\rightarrow M\leftarrow SR→M←S in (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1)
  • 2-morphisms are the usual maps between cospans

Eric Forgy (Jan 17 2021 at 00:58):

Eric Forgy (Jan 17 2021 at 01:00):

David Egolf (Jan 17 2021 at 01:02):

If it does, then we are in business! There should then be a unique μop:M→M⊗M\mu^{op}:M \to M \otimes Mμop:M→M⊗M making the flipped version of that unital law diagram commute, which is our "diagonal map".

Eric Forgy (Jan 17 2021 at 01:02):

Universal properties are unique "up to isomorphism".

Eric Forgy (Jan 17 2021 at 01:03):

So if you chase those diagrams with MMM and then chase them again with 1×M1\times M1×M, you should get the same thing up to isomorphism.

Eric Forgy (Jan 17 2021 at 01:06):

You probably know this, but elements in 1×M1\times M1×M are all of the form (∙,m).(\bullet,m).(∙,m). For every m∈Mm\in Mm∈M there is a (∙,m)∈1×M(\bullet,m)\in 1\times M(∙,m)∈1×M and those two are basically the same thing since m↦(∙,m)m\mapsto (\bullet,m)m↦(∙,m) and (∙,m)↦m(\bullet,m)\mapsto m(∙,m)↦m is an isomorphism.

David Egolf (Jan 17 2021 at 01:07):

Yeah, that's true for when we can work in ordered pairs of "elements".

Eric Forgy (Jan 17 2021 at 01:08):

So an element of (M×1)×(1×M)(M\times 1)\times (1\times M)(M×1)×(1×M) is of the form ((m1,∙),(∙,m2))((m_1, \bullet),(\bullet,m_2))((m1​,∙),(∙,m2​)) which is the same as (m1,m2)(m_1,m_2)(m1​,m2​) since there is an isomorphism between them.

David Egolf (Jan 17 2021 at 01:08):

David Egolf (Jan 17 2021 at 01:12):

Eric Forgy (Jan 17 2021 at 01:14):

Yeah. One of the whole purposes of monoidal categories, as I understand it, is that we can treat this stuff like familiar equations so that 1×1\times1× is really like multiplying by the identiy in normal algebra.

David Egolf (Jan 17 2021 at 01:15):

But if we accept all these things: M⊗MM \otimes MM⊗M together with functions η⊗1\eta \otimes 1η⊗1 and 1⊗η1 \otimes \eta1⊗η is a coproduct of I⊗MI \otimes MI⊗M and M⊗IM \otimes IM⊗I, and when we turn around the arrows it becomes a product in the opposite category of I⊗MI \otimes MI⊗M and M⊗IM \otimes IM⊗I.

Then there is a unique "diagonal map" μop:M→M⊗M\mu^{op}: M \to M \otimes Mμop:M→M⊗M so that the corresponding morphism μ\muμ makes the identity law diagram commute.

Eric Forgy (Jan 17 2021 at 01:16):

Btw, I keep writing ×\times× instead of ⊗\otimes⊗ because what we're trying to prove is only true for cartesian categories where ⊗=×.\otimes = \times.⊗=×.

Eric Forgy (Jan 17 2021 at 01:21):

David Egolf said:

I haven't figured it out yet, but I suspect there's some way of taking the guaranteed Δ\DeltaΔ and "turning it around" so that it becomes the μ\muμ we need.

This is called "op{}^\mathsf{op}op" :blush:

On the one hand, we have μ\muμ in Cop.C^\mathsf{op}.Cop. On the other we have Δ\DeltaΔ in CCC. In what we're talking about μop=Δ.\mu^\mathsf{op} = \Delta.μop=Δ. Put differently, μ\muμ in CopC^\mathsf{op}Cop is the opposite of the diagonal map Δ\DeltaΔ in CCC. That is the definition of μ.\mu.μ.

David Egolf (Jan 17 2021 at 01:22):

Summarizing a bit for myself: The key thing is this connection between the monoidal product and the cartesian product. When the monoidal product also enjoys the universal properties of the cartesian product (in some category) then we start getting unique morphisms to it. Unique morphisms to the monoidal product end up inducing a unique way to satisfy the unit laws.

Eric Forgy (Jan 17 2021 at 01:25):

So if a monoidal category (C,⊗,I)(C,\otimes,I)(C,⊗,I) has a diagonal map and a unit that is the terminal object, i.e. I=1I = 1I=1, then every object of CCC is a monoid object in (Cop,⊗,I).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes,I).(Cop,⊗,I).

BUT... those conditions are precisely the definition of a cartesian monoidal category :blush:

Hence, in a cartesian category (C,×,1)(C,\times,1)(C,×,1), every object of CCC is a monoid object in (Cop,×,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\times,1).(Cop,×,1).

David Egolf (Jan 17 2021 at 01:26):

To have a diagonal map, I think you have to have at least binary products, right?

Eric Forgy (Jan 17 2021 at 01:27):

David Egolf said:

Summarizing a bit for myself: The key thing is this connection between the monoidal product and the cartesian product. When the monoidal product also enjoys the universal properties of the cartesian product (in some category) then we start getting unique morphisms to it. Unique morphisms to the monoidal product end up inducing a unique way to satisfy the unit laws.

No. There are two conditions and they are separate. You need:

  1. Existence of diagonals
  2. The unit element must be terminal

David Egolf (Jan 17 2021 at 01:27):

Yeah, I was summarizing the "existence of diagonals" part.

Eric Forgy (Jan 17 2021 at 01:28):

If you have both of those, you have a cartesian category.

David Egolf (Jan 17 2021 at 01:29):

John Baez (Jan 17 2021 at 01:51):

David Egolf said:

I haven't figured it out yet, but I suspect there's some way of taking the guaranteed Δ\DeltaΔ and "turning it around" so that it becomes the μ\muμ we need.

Yes: If your category C\mathsf{C}C is cartesian, every object xxx in it has a diagonal Δ:x→x×x\Delta: x \to x \times xΔ:x→x×x, and then in (Cop,×,1)(\mathsf{C}^{\rm op}, \times, 1)(Cop,×,1) this becomes a morphism from x×xx \times xx×x to xxx which, you can show, is an associative multiplication - the μ\muμ you want.

John Baez (Jan 17 2021 at 01:54):

It's fun to show that this multiplication really is associative.

Some things I've (un)learned recently:

  • The unit of a monoidal category is not always terminal :face_palm:
  • The unit of a cartesian category is always terminal :cool:
  • kkk is not terminal in Vectk\mathsf{Vect}_kVectk​ (related to above, I knew kkk is the unit of Vectk\mathsf{Vect}_kVectk​) :face_palm:
  • Tensor product of modules is actually a coproduct :face_palm:

Thanks to John's puzzles, I now know one important relationship between spans and bimodules.

Span(C,×,1)\mathsf{Span}(C,\times,1)Span(C,×,1) is a bicategory where

  • (C,×,1)(C,\times,1)(C,×,1) is a cartesian category
  • Objects are objects of (C,×,1).(C,\times,1).(C,×,1).
  • Morphisms are spans in (C,×,1).(C,\times,1).(C,×,1).
  • 2-morphisms are maps between spans.

{}
Bim(C,×,1)\mathsf{Bim}(C,\times,1)Bim(C,×,1) is a bicategory where

  • (C,×,1)(C,\times,1)(C,×,1) is a cocartesian category
  • Objects are monoid objects of (C,×,1).(C,\times,1).(C,×,1).
  • Morphisms are bimodules in (C,×,1).(C,\times,1).(C,×,1).
  • 2-morphisms are bimodule morphisms.

Span(C,×,1)≅Bim(Cop,×,1),\mathsf{Span}(C,\times,1) \cong \mathsf{Bim}(C^\mathsf{op},\times,1),Span(C,×,1)≅Bim(Cop,×,1),

In other words:

  • Every object c∈(C,×,1)c\in (C,\times,1)c∈(C,×,1) is a monoid object in (Cop,×,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\times,1).(Cop,×,1).
  • Every span in (C,×,1)(C,\times,1)(C,×,1) is a bimodule in (Cop,×,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\times,1).(Cop,×,1).

{}
(Note: We never discussed 2-morphisms or bicategories, but I have enough faith in the beauty of the universe to feel fairly confident this has to be the case.)

Todd Trimble (Jan 17 2021 at 20:23):

Some corrections: "the tensor product of modules is a coproduct". It's true that (for example) the tensor product of commutative rings has, for its underlying additive abelian group, the tensor product of the additive groups of the given rings. And similarly for commutative kkk-algebras over a commutative ring kkk: you take the tensor product of their underlying (additive) kkk-modules. But that's saying something else.

On bicategories of spans: the input data needs to be a category CCC with pullbacks. Those are what allow you to compose morphisms = 1-cells. But if you want to do all the things you mention, you will need finite products as well. So you may as well assume CCC is finitely complete.

There's a pretty big iceberg of stuff that lies beyond...

I'm probably only going to respond intermittently (if at all). John has been heroically guiding you through this -- I don't have the time myself.

Some definitions:
{}
Span(C,×)\mathsf{Span}(C,\times)Span(C,×) is a bicategory where

  • (C,×)(C,\times)(C,×) is a cartesian monoidal category with pullbacks (i.e. is finitely complete)
  • Objects are objects of (C,×).(C,\times).(C,×).
  • Morphisms are spans in (C,×).(C,\times).(C,×).
  • 2-morphisms are maps between spans.

{}
Bim(Cop,×)\mathsf{Bim}(C^\mathsf{op},\times)Bim(Cop,×) is a bicategory where

  • (C,×)(C,\times)(C,×) is a cartesian monoidal category with pullbacks (i.e. is finitely complete)
  • Objects are monoid objects of (Cop,×).(C^\mathsf{op},\times).(Cop,×).
  • Morphisms are bimodules in (Cop,×).(C^\mathsf{op},\times).(Cop,×).
  • 2-morphisms are bimodule morphisms.

{}

Span(C,×)≅Bim(Cop,×).\mathsf{Span}(C,\times) \cong \mathsf{Bim}(C^\mathsf{op},\times).Span(C,×)≅Bim(Cop,×).

(as part of a desire to apply for engineering faculty positions, but I'm pretty sure I am too late for that by now :pensive:) in the language of CT in an attempt to simplify the presentation, add some exposition and extend it with some recent new results that I'm excited about.

Back in November, I roughly - very roughly - knew what a bimodule was. I thought of it as a slight generalization of vector spaces with left and right actions by commutative algebras. The bimodules I was working with were clearly related to directed graphs, but I had no idea how to make that connection precise although I knew it was there. I had heard the word "span", but had never knowingly used it in any work I was doing.

I've learned a lot these past couple months thanks to John, Todd and several others. Thank you :pray:

Span(Vectop,⊗)≅Cospan(Vect,⊗)≅Bim(Vect,⊗)\mathsf{Span(Vect^{op},\otimes)\cong Cospan(Vect,\otimes)\cong Bim(Vect,\otimes)}Span(Vectop,⊗)≅Cospan(Vect,⊗)≅Bim(Vect,⊗)
{}
so that
{}
K∙:Span(Set,×)→Bim(Vect,⊗)K^{\bullet}: \mathsf{Span(Set,\times)\to Bim(Vect,\otimes)}K∙:Span(Set,×)→Bim(Vect,⊗)
{}
and
{}
K[∙]:Span(Set,×)→Bim(Vectop,⊗)K[\bullet]: \mathsf{Span(Set,\times)\to Bim(Vect^{op},\otimes)}K[∙]:Span(Set,×)→Bim(Vectop,⊗)
[Edit: Was missing the op\mathsf{op}op when I first posted this.]
{}
so the second diagram is better thought of as
image.png

{}
This gives some solid justification for what I knew should somehow be true :+1:

Eric Forgy (Jan 20 2021 at 08:12):

I spent a few minutes looking at the bicategory Cospan(N,+)\mathsf{Cospan}(\mathbb{N,+})Cospan(N,+). It is kind of cool.

It is defined as follows:

  • There is one object ∙\bullet∙
  • Morphisms are cospans with legs labelled with natural numbers, e.g. ∙→m∙←n∙.\bullet\overset{m}{\rightarrow}\bullet\overset{n}{\leftarrow}\bullet.∙→m∙←n∙.
  • 2-morphisms are maps between cospans

{}
Composition of cospans is as usual via pushout

image.png

{}
2-morphisms

image.png

{}
are defined only if m=m2−m1=n2−n1≥0.m = m_2-m_1 = n_2-n_1\ge 0.m=m2​−m1​=n2​−n1​≥0.
{}

Just like my favorite functor
{}
N→C\mathbb{N}\to CN→C
{}
is a classifier of endomorphisms in a category CCC,
{}
Cospan(N,+)→Cospan(C,⊔)\mathsf{Cospan}(\mathbb{N},+)\to\mathsf{Cospan}(C,\sqcup)Cospan(N,+)→Cospan(C,⊔)
{}
seems to play a similar role for bicategories.
{}
N\mathbb{N}N is cocartesian so we have
{}
Cospan(N,+)≅Span(Nop,+)≅Bim(N,+)\mathsf{Cospan}(\mathbb{N},+)\cong \mathsf{Span}(\mathbb{N}^\mathsf{op},+)\cong \mathsf{Bim}(\mathbb{N},+)Cospan(N,+)≅Span(Nop,+)≅Bim(N,+)
{}
and my favorite functor becomes
{}
G:Span(Nop,+)→Span(Set,×),G: \mathsf{Span}(\mathbb{N}^\mathsf{op},+)\to \mathsf{Span(Set,\times)},G:Span(Nop,+)→Span(Set,×),
{}

  • G(∙)=VG(\bullet) = V\quadG(∙)=V (set of vertices)
  • G(∙→0∙←0∙)=V:V→VG(\bullet\overset{0}\rightarrow \bullet \overset{0}\leftarrow \bullet) = V: V\to V\quadG(∙→0∙←0∙)=V:V→V (identify span)
  • G(∙→0∙←1∙)=E:V→VG(\bullet\overset{0}\rightarrow\bullet \overset{1}\leftarrow \bullet) = E: V\to V\quadG(∙→0∙←1∙)=E:V→V (directed graph)
  • G(∙→1∙←0∙)=E†:V→VG(\bullet\overset{1}\rightarrow\bullet \overset{0}\leftarrow \bullet) = E^\dagger: V\to V\quadG(∙→1∙←0∙)=E†:V→V (same directed graph with reversed arrows, i.e. the adjoint graph)
  • G(∙→1∙←1∙)=E†∘E=E∘E†:V→VG(\bullet\overset{1}\rightarrow\bullet \overset{1}\leftarrow \bullet) = E^\dagger\circ E = E\circ E^\dagger: V\to V\quadG(∙→1∙←1∙)=E†∘E=E∘E†:V→V (directed graph composed with its adjoint)
  • G(∙→m∙←n∙)=E†×Vm∘E×Vn=E×Vn∘E†×Vm:V→VG(\bullet\overset{m}\rightarrow\bullet \overset{n}\leftarrow \bullet) = {E^\dagger}^{\times_V m}\circ E^{\times_V n} = E^{\times_V n}\circ {E^\dagger}^{\times_V m}: V\to V\quadG(∙→m∙←n∙)=E†×V​m∘E×V​n=E×V​n∘E†×V​m:V→V (adjoint paths of length mmm composed with paths of length nnn)

{}
This definitely feels like I'm on track :+1:

Eric Forgy (Jan 20 2021 at 09:29):

Eric Forgy said:

Now, I think I can pose a question I raised above more correctly:
{}
Is it possible that
{}
[Span(Nop,+),Span(Set,×)]≅Span([(Nop,+),(Set,×)],×)[\mathsf{Span}(\mathbb{N}^\mathsf{op},+),\mathsf{Span(Set,\times)}] \cong \mathsf{Span}([(\mathbb{N}^\mathsf{op},+),(\mathsf{Set},\times)],\times)[Span(Nop,+),Span(Set,×)]≅Span([(Nop,+),(Set,×)],×)
{}
?

Between shifus John and Todd, I think I might have learned enough CT kung fu that I might actually be able to take at stab at this :muscle:

Consider the following diagram

image.png

{}
The action of a functor
{}
Span(Nop,+)→Span(Set,×)\mathsf{Span}(\mathbb{N}^\mathsf{op},+)\to\mathsf{Span(Set,\times)}Span(Nop,+)→Span(Set,×)
{}
is shown on the left and on the right sides of the commuting box. The horizontal arrows connecting the left and right sides are components of a natural transformation.
{}
The action of a functor
{}
(Nop,+)→(Set,×)(\mathbb{N}^\mathsf{op},+)\to (\mathsf{Set},\times)(Nop,+)→(Set,×)
{}
is again shown on the left and on the right sides of the commuting box. The horizontal arrows connecting the left and right sides are components of a natural transformation.

However, we can insert another functor resulting in the following diagram

image.png

{}
This looks like a span of functors, i.e. one functor in the middle with functors on either side and natural transformations connecting them, so I think it might actually be possible that
{}
[Span(Nop,+),Span(Set,×)]≅Span([(Nop,+),(Set,×)],×).[\mathsf{Span}(\mathbb{N}^\mathsf{op},+),\mathsf{Span(Set,\times)}] \cong \mathsf{Span}([(\mathbb{N}^\mathsf{op},+),(\mathsf{Set},\times)],\times).[Span(Nop,+),Span(Set,×)]≅Span([(Nop,+),(Set,×)],×).
{}
I know this doesn't count as a proof, but I think it might be a reasonable sketch of the beginning of a proof (with possible modifications) :blush:

Eric Forgy (Jan 20 2021 at 09:41):

Note: In the diagram, I introduced a new shorthand notation
{}
Em,n:=E†×Vm∘E×Vn=E×Vn∘E†×VmE^{m,n} := {E^\dagger}^{\times_V m}\circ E^{\times_V n} = E^{\times_V n}\circ {E^\dagger}^{\times_V m}Em,n:=E†×V​m∘E×V​n=E×V​n∘E†×V​m
{}
so that
{}
E0,0=V,E^{0,0} = V,E0,0=V,
{}
E0,1=E,E^{0,1} = E,E0,1=E,
{}
and
{}
E1,0=E†.E^{1,0} = E^\dagger.E1,0=E†.
